title: Why do Chinese names consist of two or three characters? - Quora

response.answer_text: The first character is the surname / family name. The second character is typically the generational name. This means that all offspring within the same generation would share the same generational name. Depending on the family’s practice, the generational name may be different between boys and girls. The third character is typically what Westerners would call the given name. The reason I say ‘typically’ is because in some cases, the positions of the generational and given names are swapped around. So, to cite a simple example, a Mr. & Mrs. Lee Thiam Wee 李添偉 could have two sons Lee Kian Beng 李建明 and Lee Kian Seng 李建成 (where Kian 建 is the boys’ generational name), and two daughters Lee Poh Chu 李寶珠 and Lee Poh Gek 李寶玉 (where Poh 寶 is the girls’ generational name). One classic example is the Khoo 邱 clan of Penang (Malaysia). To this day, the Khoo’s maintain the tradition of giving names to their offspring based on a 40-character genealogy chart below (Source: Leong San Tong Khoo Kongsi). This is not limited to just one Khoo 邱 family, but the entire Khoo 邱 clan (cousins, second and third cousins, and way beyond).  What this means is that a Mr. Khoo Soo Teck 邱思德 could bump into a total stranger called Mr. Khoo Soo Jit 邱思日, and they could both identify themselves as probably very distant cousins belonging to the 20th generation of the Khoo 邱 clan, calculated from the time of the progenitor of the Khoo 邱 clan. Due to large age differences amplified over successive generations, it may even be that Mr. Khoo Soo Teck 邱思德 and Mr. Khoo Soo Jit 邱思日 could have an age difference of thirty to forty years! At the time of writing, the Khoo’s have reached more or less the 27th generation (i.e. Kar 家). Once they reach the 40th generation, the poem is expected to repeat itself from the beginning. (By the way, for Mandarin speakers who are baffled by my seemingly-alien choice of phonetics above, I am using the Hokkien 福建 or Minnan 閩南 dialect for pronouncing the Chinese characters.) In cases where a Chinese name comprises only two characters instead of three, it implies that the parents of the person have chosen to drop the generational name (not uncommon among single-child families), or that the person himself/herself has opted to drop his generational name for convenience (a common practice among lone first-generation migrants from China - my own great-grandfather was an example).

Good question. It’s rather confusing when one or two of the three character could be the last name 姓 and one or two characters could be the first name 名. First thing is to know which one is which. It was not always that first name first and last name last. When I was a kid, I love watching the 007 series when Sean Connery said: “My name is Bond, James Bond”. Classic and left a long lasting impression for me to start introduce myself that way. The name is Wong, Joseph Wong. My name pronounce as Wang E Tzu 王 一 柱 in Mandarin (high tone) or Wong Yah Qu in Cantonese (low tone). E or Yah 一 means ONE in English and 柱Tzu or Qu means post. 王 Wang is Mandarin and Wong is Cantonese for the same last name which means king, the family surname. I was also known by friends as 黑 Huck means black in Cantonese for coming out of the oven (womb) like a charcoal. There are over thousands of family surnames with most commonly known last names listed in a book called 百家姓 “The Hundred Family Surnames”. See here Chinese surname - Wikipedia You can also see additional details about last names in Wei Zhen’s answer. Legend has it that the surnames were collected during Ming Dynasty in the manner that has no rhyme or reason other than the author’s will and/or who’s in charge. The first family surname in the book is 趙 Chao which happen to be last name of the first Ming Emperor. Second is 錢 Cheng, which means money. Third is 孫 Sun, means grandson. Followed by 李 Li; which could mean plum or 十八子 the eighteen’s son. My family surname is 王 Wong/Wang, landed the number eight spot in the book. If the last name only contains one character then the other one or two characters usually are the first name and middle name. People with 複姓 double characters for last name sometimes ended up with four character names if middle name was included. 司馬 Si-Ma, 歐陽 Au-Yang, 慕容 Moo-Yung are common two character surnames. What’s in a name but how you are being remembered by others. Is it really that a rose by any other name is a rose? Not to the Chinese, educated people would never name their kids 花 Hua, 牛 New, 豬 Ju, 狗 Go, but they are common names for folks came from 鄕下 country villages. 明 Ming means bright, 山 Shan means mountain, Nell 鳥 (bird) is rare but 鷹 Ying (eagle) is popular clearly showing size does matters. 妺 梅 Mei could be or means 妹 little sister or 梅 Chinese Blossom. Chinese is not like the show “Name that tune”。 It’s rather difficult to provide you Chinese name meanings because they are being used phonetically. When introduced; people would explain to you what their name means and that’s the best way to find what what’s what and who’s who. By the way, do you know what John and Mary means? When I name my son Douglas; I didn’t know it meant from dark waters and my daughter’s name Sheena was just like Jane in England. Go figure.
